Content.Name: BS in Child Development
Content.Title: BS in Child Development
Content.BodyCopy:
Outcome/Standard 1. Understanding and Applying Developmental Knowledge
Knowledge: Identify and describe the characteristics, needs, and influences associated with typical development, and recognize patterns of atypical development; demonstrate an introductory understanding of the major developmental theories and accepted methods of scientific inquiry in the biological, cognitive and behavioral sciences.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Skills: Use developmental knowledge to create healthy, respectful, supportive, and challenging environments for children.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Disposition:  Reflect on and appropriately adjust our own practices to promote positive outcomes for each child.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Outcome/Standard 2. Building Family and Community Relationships
Knowledge:  Recognize and understand the family and community characteristics and ecological influences necessary for supporting and empowering families and communities in diverse cultural contexts.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Skills:  Use respectful and reciprocal relationships and orchestrated activities to engage families and communities in the development and learning of children.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Disposition:  Reflect on/make explicit own values and biases related to differences in family and community culture, structure, etc.  Identify and acknowledge shared, ‘unifying’ values.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Outcome/Standard 3. Observing, Documenting, and Assessing to Support Children and Families
Knowledge:  Understand the characteristics, benefits, and tools of responsible assessment.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
  • Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Skills: Practice responsible assessment using appropriate observation, documentation, and assessment tools or instruments, while effectively partnering with families and professional colleagues.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Disposition:  Be observant, curious and committed to documentation; be willing to make appropriate referrals in order to increase the likelihood of early and accurate diagnosis of atypical development.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Outcome/Standard 4.  Planning and delivering intentional programming for children
Knowledge:  Understand the central concepts for successful program planning (Purpose, Content, Target Audience, Space, Materials) and delivery (Methods, Admin Principles and Evaluation)
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Skills:  Use knowledge, appropriate standards and effective administrative principles to design, implement and evaluate meaningful programming for each child.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Disposition:  Be a critical thinker/informed consumer.  Be committed to use knowledge, appropriate learning standards, and other resources to design, implement, and evaluate meaningful, challenging programming for each child.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Standard 5. Becoming a Professional
Knowledge:  Know the professional associations, practices, and ethical standards and guidelines necessary for full participation.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Skills:  Uphold ethical standards and participate in continuous, collaborative learning to inform practice; Convey effectively through oral and written communication basic developmental concepts, concerns, processes and recommendations.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
Disposition:  Identify and involve oneself as a childhood professional who confidently defends, advocates for and promote measures to strengthen children and families in professional, family, church and community settings as a conscientious and engaged citizen.
Evidence of Learning: Direct Measure
Evidence of Learning: Indirect Measure
The evidence suggests that . . .
